clinical_study.brief_title: Ibuprofen Compared to Morphine as a Pediatric Postoperative Pain Management Tool Following Inguinal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Assessing the Effectiveness of Ibuprofen Compared to Morphine as a Pediatric Postoperative Pain Management Tool Following Inguinal Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Morphine is now the most commonly used opioid in children for pain management even though the safety of morphine use in children is a primary concern for parents as it is perceived to have more associated risks. Ibuprofen and other Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) have also been shown to be effective for the management of postoperative pain with fewer associated adverse effects. However, there have been concerns that utilization of ibuprofen alone may lead to inadequate pain management. Evidence of whether ibuprofen is equally effective as morphine for postoperative pain control in pediatric inguinal surgery is lacking and needs to be further explored as a measure to potentially reduce opioid exposure in children. To determine which drug is more effective for relieving post-operative pain, this trial will compare the effectiveness of ibuprofen and morphine at reducing post-operative pain, and the amount of analgesic use required post-surgery.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Measure at admission to the Post Anesthetic Care Unit (PACU) after surgery. Patient is typically admitted to the PACU within 30 minutes of surgical procedure being completed. It is at this point that the initial pain score will be determined.
primary_outcome.description: Pain scores will be measured through a reliable and validated observer-rated Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS) by two trained, blinded, and independent study personnel. Both study personnel will measure pain at admission during the recovery phase.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured dosage post-surgery (on average 45 minutes later)
secondary_outcome.description: Defined as the number of doses of Tylenol (15mg/kg) administered by PACU and SDSU nurses following surgery. Parents will record supplemental Tylenol administered in a pain diary for both arms of the study

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the time surgical procedure is completed to discharge from the hospital. (Typically two to four hours)
secondary_outcome.description: The frequency of emesis (vomiting) will be recorded by nurses at the recovery unit (post anesthetic care unit and same day surgery unit) during the patient's hospital stay.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time from the end of the surgical procedure to discharge from hospital. (Typically two to four hours)
secondary_outcome.description: The time it takes for the patient to be discharged from the hospital, beginning from when they first complete surgery.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any complications that arise during the patient's recovery at the hospital (Typically two to four hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Any complications that arise with the patient, during their recovery in the hospital.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Surgical complications will be seen at the patient's 48-hour follow-up visit.
secondary_outcome.description: Any surgical complications that arise during the patient's surgery (surgical site infection, bleeding, wound dehiscence) will be assessed by a physician or nurse practitioner at 48-will be seen by the physician or nurse practitioner at the patient's 48-hour follow-up visit.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The first bowel movement for the patient after surgery (Immediately after surgery to 3 Days post surgery)
secondary_outcome.description: The first bowel movement post-surgery for the patient (during hospital stay or at home).

arm_group.description: Ibuprofen suspension (Advil) will be administered orally at a dose of 10mg/kg every 6 hours for 72 hours post-surgery.
Morphine sulfate suspension will be administered orally at a dose of 0.02 - 0.04 mg/kg every 6 hours for 72 hours post-surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Pediatric Patients between the ages of 10 months-5 years at presentation to clinic
2. Patients diagnosed with inguinal hernia or hydrocele, or undescended testes requiring surgical intervention by a trained physician
3. Patients requiring inguinal day surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients who have undergone previous inguinal surgery
2. Patients with other co-morbidities
3. Patients unable to be prescribed Ibuprofen or Morphine
4. Chronic use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) or opioids
5. Inability of parent/guardian to fluently understand English
6. Patients with renal or hepatic failure
7. Patients with coagulation disorders
8. Deviation to pre-established anesthesia protocol
